stem: The nurse is reviewing overnight blood glucose logs for two clients with Type 1 Diabetes. Based on the documentation in the Overnight Glucose Monitoring Log, match each trend with its correct clinical phenomenon and intervention.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: Reports waking up with a headache and 'night sweats'. Fasting blood glucose (FBG) is consistently > 200 mg/dL. 
Patient B: Reports no nighttime symptoms but FBG is also consistently high (> 180 mg/dL).

tabs.title: Overnight Glucose Monitoring Log
tabs.content:
Patient10:00 PM (Bedtime)02:00 AM (Mid-night)07:00 AM (Morning)
Patient A110 mg/dL54 mg/dL (Low)240 mg/dL (High)
Patient B120 mg/dL130 mg/dL (Normal)190 mg/dL (High)

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
Patient A: HR 110 bpm at 02:00 AM (during low). 
Patient B: Stable.

rows.text: Low glucose at 02:00 AM followed by high glucose at 07:00 AM
Normal/High glucose at 02:00 AM followed by high glucose at 07:00 AM
Intervention: Decrease the evening NPH insulin dose or provide a bedtime snack
Intervention: Increase the evening NPH insulin dose or delay the injection time

rationale.correct: The **Somogyi Effect** (c1) is characterized by a mid-night dip (hypoglycemia) at 02:00 AM, which triggers a rebound hyperglycemia (morning high) (r1). The fix is to provide more sugar (snack) or less insulin at night (r3). The **Dawn Phenomenon** (c2) is a result of growth hormone release, showing steady/normal glucose mid-night followed by a morning rise (r2). The fix is to increase night coverage (r4).
clinicalPearls: Dawn = 'Down with hormones' (High all night until morning).
Headaches and sweats are classic clues for the Somogyi mid-night low.

questionTrap.trap: Intervening for a 7:00 AM high without checking the 2:00 AM level.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: You MUST know the 2:00 AM level to decide whether to give MORE or LESS insulin. If you give more insulin to a Somogyi patient, you might cause severe hypoglycemia.

mnemonic.title: S for Somogyi
mnemonic.expansion: Somogyi = Sips down at night. Dawn = Double-high.
